hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the input data. You have a list of salaries associated with different employees and companies. Each entry contains a company ID, employee ID, employee name, and salary.
Consider how you might group the salaries by company ID. You can use a dictionary or a similar data structure to accumulate salaries for each company.
When grouping the salaries, think about how to initialize your data structure. For each company ID, you will want to start with a total salary of zero.
As you iterate through the rows of salaries, remember to check if the company ID already exists in your accumulator. If it does, you will add the current salary to the existing total.
Don't forget to handle the case where a company ID appears for the first time. You will need to create a new entry in your accumulator for that company ID.
After accumulating the salaries, consider how you will format your output. You may want to create a list of total salaries by company ID.
Think about edge cases, such as when a company has no employees or when all employees have the same salary. How will your solution handle these scenarios?
Ensure that your output is sorted by company ID. This will likely require you to sort your final results before returning them.
As you prepare to return the results, consider the format you need to use. You should return a list of dictionaries or tuples, each containing a company ID and the corresponding total salary.
Finally, make sure to test your solution with the provided sample test case and additional cases to ensure it works correctly. Pay attention to the expected output format.

questionNotes: Input data is structured as a list of lists, with each inner list containing [company_id, employee_id, employee_name, salary].
You need to group salaries by company_id and return the total salary for each company.
Handle cases where companies have no employees or where all salaries are the same.
Output should be sorted by company_id and formatted as a list of [company_id, total_salary].
